title: WhatsApp sues Israeli spyware company over digital spying exposed by U of T group
text:
WhatsApp, the encrypted messaging platform owned by Facebook Inc., is suing an Israeli spyware company after the University of Toronto research group Citizen Lab exposed a major digital spying effort targeting the platform earlier this year.

The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California on Tuesday, alleges that in April and May of 2019 a technical vulnerability in WhatsApp’s platform allowed attackers to install malware on around 1,400 phones, allowing for covert digital surveillance.

In the lawsuit filed Tuesday, WhatsApp is seeking a judicial order that NSO Group, which is also known as Q Cyber, be permanently banned from using WhatsApp and all other Facebook properties, in addition to financial compensation.

The revelation that as many as 1,400 people were affected, including “attorneys, journalists, human rights activists, political dissidents, diplomats, and other senior foreign government officials,” according to the lawsuit, widens the scope of the alleged surveillance significantly.

When Citizen Lab wrote about the issue in May, their blog post noted that, “Despite still being in the early stages of its investigation, a WhatsApp spokesperson did not deny that the number of users targeted with this spyware ‘could range in the dozens.’”

Citizen Lab discovered the vulnerability in WhatsApp after a human rights lawyer contacted the organization about phone calls “at odd hours from an unknown Swedish number.” The lawyer was working for people who had been previously targeted by NSO Group.

In an emailed statement to the Financial Post, NSO vehemently denied the allegations.

“Our technology is not designed or licensed for use against human rights activists and journalists. It has helped to save thousands of lives over recent years,” the emailed statement said.

“The truth is that strongly encrypted platforms are often used by pedophile rings, drug kingpins and terrorists to shield their criminal activity. Without sophisticated technologies, the law enforcement agencies meant to keep us all safe face insurmountable hurdles. NSO’s technologies provide proportionate, lawful solutions to this issue.”

But in a new blog post Tuesday, Citizen Lab singled out NSO Group for its questionable track record.

“Among the many companies Citizen Lab has tracked, NSO group stands out in terms of the reckless abuse of its spyware by government clients,” Citizen Lab said.

“Although the technology is marketed as a tool to assist governments in lawful investigations into crime and terrorism, Citizen Lab has identified dozens of cases where journalists, human rights activists and defenders, lawyers, international investigators, political opposition groups, and other members of civil society have been targeted with its spyware, called ‘Pegasus.’”

According to Citizen Lab, Pegasus is NSO Group’s flagship software, and it allows attackers to obtain passwords, contact lists, calendar events, text messages and live phone calls once a device is infected. The attackers using Pegasus can even remotely turn on the phone’s camera and microphone, and track movements using GPS.

In an op-ed in the Washington Post published concurrently with the lawsuit, WhatsApp head Will Cathcart said that this kind of surveillance must stop.

“There was another disturbing pattern to the attack, as our lawsuit explains. It targeted at least 100 human-rights defenders, journalists and other members of civil society across the world,” Cathcart wrote.

“This should serve as a wake-up call for technology companies, governments and all Internet users. Tools that enable surveillance into our private lives are being abused, and the proliferation of this technology into the hands of irresponsible companies and governments puts us all at risk.”
